‘Hedda' Review: Tessa Thompson Is the Ultimate Party Monster in Nia DaCosta's Vivacious Ibsen Adaptation
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-09-08 14:33:20

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. Words like “bold” and “daring” and “wild” will be thrown around — really, have already been thrown around — in regards to Nia DaCosta's “Hedda,” one of the more original and thrilling adaptations of a classic work in recent memory. The same words apply to the title character at the film‘s center, the inscrutable and seemingly unscrupulous Hedda Gabler (a magnetic Tessa Thompson), here yanked firmly from the late 20th century setting of Henrik Ibsen's iconic play into the '50s, and not missing a single trick along the way. The time setting is hardly the only thing DaCosta, who also wrote the film's screenplay has changed here, which now imagines Hedda to be a Black woman (one supporting character marvels at her “dusky” skin) whose love affairs involve both men and women. The former flame who shows up at her sprawling (read: unaffordable) country home for a raucous (read: deadly) party is, in DaCosta's telling, now a woman: Eileen Lovborg, no longer Eilert Lovborg. Again, bold and daring and wild changes, sure, but also imaginative and illuminating. Which is to say: this all works, very well. Popular on IndieWire Related Stories Charlie Kaufman on His Short ‘How to Shoot a Ghost,' How ‘Synecdoche, New York' Has Only Gotten More Love with Time, and Upcoming Projects How Paul Greengrass Shot ‘The Lost Bus' with a Real School Bus and an Actual Fire, with Matthew McConaughey and Producer Jamie Lee Curtis The film opens the morning after Hedda's party, thrown to celebrate Hedda and her husband George Tesman's (Tom Bateman) entrance into society. What the party is really thrown for is something far less mundane: In seeking to please Hedda, struggling professor George has purchased the pair a lush, lavish country estate they can absolutely not afford (production designer Cara Brower's work is stunning, and makes it easy to see why anyone would go half-mad to live here). They've been assisted by Hedda's long-time family friend Judge Roland Brack (Nicholas Pinnock), who takes every opportunity to try to ravish a disgusted Hedda, clearly believing he's owed something. But George has hopes that the Tesmans might soon not owe anyone anything, as they've invited university muckity-muck Professor Greenwood (Finbar Lynch) to the party, and they hope to impress him so very much that he'll give George a cushy new job (and, you know, money). And this party is going to be grand indeed, molded to Hedda's particular taste as possible — less flowers, more champagne — and kitted out with a guest list that proves more bizarre as the night winds on. For Hedda, a woman defined by the many constraints that hold her (familial, professional, societal, racial, sexual, the list goes on and on), a party is something she can really control and make her own. More to the point: a party's guests are something she can really control and make her own. While the constantly cowed George thinks this is all for him, Hedda has other ideas. Also on their way to the mansion: Eileen Lovborg, Hedda's former flame, George's current rival for that new gig, and apparently some sort of changed person. When Hedda and Eileen were wild together, Eileen's drinking and carousing was a problem, but she's put all that wickedness behind her, mostly thanks to the love of Thea Clifton (a delicate Imogen Poots), who has also just arrived at the mansion for the world's worst party. Thea, of all people, sees Hedda most clearly: as the women reacquaint themselves before Eileen's promised arrival, she muses that Hedda was “terrifying” when they first knew each other in school. That has not abated, but Hedda's reign of terror will find new ways to out itself (and her) over the course of one devastating party. Upstairs, in one of the mansion's many jewel box rooms, Hedda displays her most prized collection: a set of guns handed down to her by her later father General Gabler, which she toys with, tosses around, and loans out, all depending on her whims. In the bottom of the guns' shiny box, there's a shallow reserve, just big enough to hide… well, you'll see. Since Ibsen first introduced Hedda in 1891, she's served as one of the theater's great anti-heroines. What she refers to as her “whimsicality” is something far richer (or wilder, bolder, take your pick): in being so repressed and restrained, it's only a matter of time that someone as singular as Hedda is going to combust. That she opts to do that at a party? Well, that's just sort of fun. Until it very much is not. Unable to control nearly everything about her life, despite making nothing but safe choices (“safe choices,” thy name is George Tesman), Hedda cannot hold. Conventionality does not offer the protection she expected it to, and so the pain is doubled: she didn't do want she wanted, and she still has nothing to show for it. When Eileen finally swoops into the party (the great Nina Hoss is so electric in her entrance, it's nearly the only moment we're distracted from Thompson, who is riveting in every moment), all bets are suddenly off. Hedda, so determined to be mistress of her own emotions, is felled. This is the great love of her life, and she arrives reborn, in love with someone else, with her next great book literally tucked under her arm, and free of the influence of booze and bad decisions. Hedda, of course, takes this all as a challenge. Thorny, pissed-off, and hellbent on shaping anything she can to her liking, Hedda stalks around the party, needles here, pushes there, and joyfully takes stock at where her machinations are getting her. Thea falls apart. Eileen falls headfirst into a cocktail. Hedda's rage is so potent that it impacts others seemingly out of her purview, and as the party pushes far into the night, the only question isn't what will happen next, but how horrific it will be. And yet. Hedda's magnetism is undeniable, and that people would be under her thrall is understandable. DaCosta and a talented team of craftspeople bolster that idea at every turn: Sean Bobbitt's cinematography is lush and oversaturated, Hildur Guðnadóttir's unpredictable score fuels the party atmosphere with a tinge of dread, and Lindsay Pugh's costumes are sumptuous. There is always something to look at or touch or hear in the mansion, enough that it can almost distract from the evils Hedda is perpetrating, against both herself and others. At one point, a guest who doesn't know Hedda tells her he's heard of her past, that before she was domesticated, she was “like fire.” That flame is still burning in “Hedda” (and in Hedda), but that brightness masks its true nature: destruction. But, oh, what fun to stand back and let it shine, at least for one evening. “Hedda” premiered at the 2025 Toronto International Film Festival. Amazon MGM will release the film in select theaters on Wednesday, October 22 and then globally on Prime Video on Wednesday, October 29. Want to stay up to date on IndieWire's film reviews and critical thoughts? Subscribe here to our newly launched newsletter, In Review by David Ehrlich, in which our Chief Film Critic and Head Reviews Editor rounds up the best new reviews and streaming picks along with some exclusive musings — all only available to subscribers. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Bob Dylan Has Become the Invisible Man Onstage, and We Have Only Ourselves to Blame
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-09-08 14:29:22

By Andy Greene Six years ago, near the end of a show in Austria, Bob Dylan grew so enraged by fans taking photos and shooting video that he stopped the set, narrowly avoided a nasty fall, and delivered an extraordinarily rare rebuke to the audience. “Take pictures or don't take pictures,” he snapped. “We can either play or we can pose. OK?” In recent years, fans at his headline shows weren't given that choice, since phones have been banned. To enforce the rule, ushers roam the aisles with flashlights and threaten to remove anyone not in compliance. The result is a refreshingly old-school concert experience where people actually watch the action on the stage and live in the moment. No real effort is made to stop audio bootleggers, and pristine tapes of these shows have emerged, but the video documentation is scattershot and borderline unwatchable since the rule-breakers are often miles from the stage and forced to film at covert angles. Last summer, however, Dylan signed onto Willie Nelson's Outlaw Music Festival, a big tour that exclusively hits amphitheaters that seat up upward of 20,000 people. It's simply not viable to ban phones at these events — no one has time to monitor that many seats — meaning that Dylan was playing to a vast sea of iPhones for the first time in years. The upside is that when set list news happened, like the return of “Mr. Tambourine Man” after 15 years or a surprise Pogues cover, everyone got to see it on YouTube the next morning. The downside is that Dylan was likely feeling very annoyed the whole time. When the Outlaw tour resumed Friday night in Bangor, Maine, after a four-week hiatus, Dylan took the drastic measure of making himself practically invisible onstage. He did this by sitting behind a grand piano, raising the music stand, surrounding himself with four very bright lights, and pulling a hoodie tight over his head. According to fan reports, people even in the first few rows were unable to see anything but the top of his hood. To the rest of the crowd, he was little more than a visual smudge behind the piano, presuming they were able to see any trace of him at all. Editor's picks The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time 100 Best Movies of the 21st Century “In my 20 years of Dylan shows, I've never witnessed anything like it,” Dylan superfan Ray Padgett wrote in his indispensable Flagging Down the Double E's newsletter. “The bigger problem wasn't that I personally had a bad view. Boo-hoo me! It was that it created the bleakest crowd energy I've experienced at one of these Outlaw shows. People were pissed.” He continued to describe the crowd's discontent in colorful terms. “One person near me spent the first half loudly complaining to anyone within earshot, aggressively offering her binoculars around to prove they don't help anyway,” Padgett wrote. “Another person, who'd apparently been stewing quietly, finally yelled ‘What the fuck!' during ‘Blind Willie McTell' and started shoving people out of the way to leave. Most humorously, two others near me got into a long mid-show debate about whether that really was Dylan up there, or an imposter.” It's not an imposter. That's the real Bob Dylan. He's just really, really tired of people watching the show through their cellphones as opposed to their own eyes. And why shouldn't he be? Phones have made concerts almost unbearable at times. (I wrote about this problem at length in 2013, and it's only gotten worse since then.) At an Oasis show the other night in Pasadena, California, many people around me barely glanced at the stage. They were too busy taking photos of each other, shooting segments of songs, and then uploading the images to social-media platforms. The rest of us were blinded by those concertgoers' screens, and mere extras in their photo shoots. Trending Stories U.S. Open Crowd Booed Trump Repeatedly MTV VMAs 2025: See the Complete Winners List Ozzy Osbourne VMAs Tribute: Steven Tyler, Joe Perry, and Yungblud Bark at the Moon Person Rick Davies, Supertramp Co-Founder and Singer, Dead at 81 The entire point of a concert is to experience something cool that's happening here in the physical world, right in front of you. What's the point of even going if you're going to spend the whole time on your phone? The photos you're taking look like absolute shit, and there's 6,000 other people filming every song. If you want to see it again, go on YouTube the next day. You don't have to make the video yourself. As George Costanza famously said, “We are living in a society.” If we don't start acting like it, Bob Dylan might start looking even more like the Invisible Man onstage, or maybe he'll simply sing from his dressing room. In the meantime, put down your damn phones. Bob has had enough. (And yes, we can't be 100 percent sure that this is why he's done everything possible to disappear himself at recent shows. But we can't imagine any other explanation.) We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rolling Stone is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Rolling Stone, LLC. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Robin Wright and Olivia Cooke face off in doting-mom thriller The Girlfriend
Source: AV Club    Published: 2025-09-08 13:10:34

From Psycho and The Manchurian Candidate to The Waterboy and Momma's Man, momma's boys have been an onscreen staple for decades. And Daniel Sanderson (Mary & George's Laurie Davidson), the med-student son of Robin Wright's glamorous gallerist Laura in Prime Video's The Girlfriend, is a textbook case—so much so that when we first meet the close mother-son duo, affectionately wrestling in the indoor pool of their posh London home, you'd be forgiven for assuming they were lovers. But soon enough, Laura's sweet life in her sweet home with her sweet son sours with the arrival of a particularly tart fruit: Cherry. Cherry Laine (Olivia Cooke) is Daniel's new girlfriend, and Laura doesn't approve: not of her name (admittedly stripper-worthy), not of her low-cut red dress (admittedly inappropriate for meeting the parents), and not of her son's hand that Cherry allows to creep scandalously high on her thigh in the middle of dinner. Even when Laura does try to get to know the maraschino-haired young woman, she's left with even more questions and concerns. Did Cherry really attend St. Florian's private school? Does she recognize the paintings that line the walls of Laura's home, or did she just conveniently memorize the excerpts off a nearby coffee-table book? And did she pocket one of Laura's gold bracelets and not-so-accidentally let the family cat loose? What, exactly, is Cherry hiding? Helpfully, every episode of the six-part domestic thriller is split into two halves, one following Laura's point of view and the other giving the same order of events from Cherry's perspective. That red dress Cherry wears to meet Daniel's folks? She can't actually afford it and panics when Laura spills coffee on the garment, which still has its tags on it. You see, while Laura's moneyed life is as carefully curated as one of her galleries—from her artfully minimalist wardrobe to the family's sunny vacation home in Spain to even the mistress she allows her husband Howard (Waleed Zuaiter) to keep on the side—Cherry's working-class background is far less tidy, one marked by scrappy determination and social ambition. Through this dual-narrator format—which faithfully follows the framework of Michelle Francis' 2017 novel of the same name, on which the series is based—we get to see not only how major plot points differ in the women's minds but also the smaller, knottier stuff: a micro aggression here, a tremor of tension there. A hurtful slight that one finds significant enough to linger on is barely mentioned in the other POV, showing how each mindset, memory, and even ego can bend and buckle the truth. It's a clash the two actors clearly relish, each gamely playing victim or villain depending on which outlook is at the forefront. (As well as starring, Wright is an executive producer on the project and directed half of its episodes. The others were helmed by Andrea Harkin.) It's in this deliberate gray area that The Girlfriend succeeds: Is Laura simply being protective—an understandable byproduct of tragically losing her first child, Daniel's sister Rose—or is she paranoid to the point of no return? Is Cherry merely self-conscious of her humble upbringing or is she a manipulative maniac? It's when the limited series gets too sure of who the bad guy really is that it loses its addictiveness, its pulpy predictability lumping it in with other rich-white-people psycho-thrillers. Speaking of, the show's soundtrack certainly doesn't help, echoing both the unsettling vocalizations of The White Lotus as well as memorable needle drops from Big Little Lies. And while Wright and Cooke are given abundant material to work with as each woman descends further and further into monsters-in-law madness, the rest of the cast is left wanting (though Zuaiter does have several quietly devastating moments as a father dulled by grief). Davidson's Daniel has boyish charm and Paul Mescal-esque good looks, sure, but the character is so blandly written and improbably oblivious (the dude is supposed to be surgeon-level smart, mind you) that you have to wonder why two alpha females like Laura and Cherry would be at each other's throats over the dimple-cheeked dolt. Unburdened by that additional story weight, the increasingly outlandish actions of our leads do keep things light, lean, and moving swiftly along, a plus when the mystery has largely been removed from the narrative. And while most thrill seekers might disapprove of the lack of startling twists and turns throughout the show's six installments, The Girlfriend finds ripe drama in the interpersonal, offering up fruitful things to say about perspective, prejudice, and possessiveness. Cherry and Laura's feud alone is juicy enough to warrant a bite. The Girlfriend premieres September 10 on Prime Video GET A.V.CLUB RIGHT IN YOUR INBOX Pop culture obsessives writing for the pop culture obsessed. By Saloni Gajjar September 1, 2025 | 2:00pm Paste Media JEZEBELAmy Coney Barrett Told Bari Weiss We Should All Just Trust the Supreme Court PASTERian Johnson Takes His Murder-Mystery Series to Exhausting Ends in Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery SPLINTERLabor Movements Are Enjoying a Resurgence Amidst Historically Weak Union Membership ENDLESS MODEMetal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater Reignites A 20-Year Debate Over Ocelot © 2025 Paste Media Group. ‘Wake Up Dead Man' Teaser: Daniel Craig's Benoit Blanc Returns for a Darker Mystery
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-09-08 13:01:36

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. Benoit Blanc is back! And riding the best reviews for one of his whodunnits since the original “Knives Out” premiered in 2019. Like that film and its slightly less well-regarded sequel “Glass Onion,” the new installment, “Wake Up Dead Man” premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival. IndieWire's Kate Erbland, in a B+ “Critic's Pick” review from the fest, said that this new entry is darker than the previous ones and draws inspiration from Edgar Allen Poe. The first teaser for “Wake Up Dead Man” is below. The Netflix film will be released in theaters November 26 and stream December 12. Its director, and franchise mastermind, Rian Johnson has proven himself a master of the whodunnit form with these films, showing a knack for Agatha Christie puzzle-plotting that, well, the actual adapters of Christie haven't shown in recent years. Not just the broad strokes like sprawling ensemble casts of big personalities, a quirky private dick in Daniel Craig‘s Blanc, endless red herrings, and an extended “reveal” of the killer, but small, subtle details: Like how Johnson repurposed the curved font on a 1980s paperback release of Christie's “Curtain” as his “Knives Out” font. The man knows his stuff. Popular on IndieWire Related Stories Charlie Kaufman on His Short ‘How to Shoot a Ghost,' How ‘Synecdoche, New York' Has Only Gotten More Love with Time, and Upcoming Projects ‘Hedda' Review: Tessa Thompson Is the Ultimate Party Monster in Nia DaCosta's Vivacious Ibsen Adaptation “Wake Up Dead Man” takes on this current moment of misinformation (one character says, “There's GOD in DOGE”) and offers a particularly great foil in Josh O'Connor, who is either a suspect for Blanc or someone who can team up with him. He's joined by another (somewhat literal) murderers' row of actors including Glenn Close, Josh Brolin, Mila Kunis, Kerry Washington, Cailee Spaeny, Andrew Scott, and Thomas Haden Church. Plus, Jeremy Renner intriguingly not playing himself — the real-life Jeremy Renner, though not appearing in “Glass Onion,” was mentioned and his likeness featured on a vanity hot sauce called “Renning Hot.” Maybe it was those kind of touches that made “Glass Onion” arguably less beloved than “Knives Out” itself? A lengthy prologue before all the characters assembled and the plot could begin certainly didn't help. Regardless, though, like its predecessor, “Glass Onion” received a screenplay nomination at the Academy Awards (adapted in that case, since it was a sequel, to the first film's original screenplay nod). “Wake Up Dead Man” will hit theaters November 26 before streaming on Netflix December 12. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


MTV VMAs 2025: Sabrina Carpenter, Ariana Grande, Lady Gaga Rescue an Otherwise Lacking Show
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-09-08 11:15:47

By Rob Sheffield “This world, as we all know, can be so full of criticism and discrimination and negativity,” Sabrina Carpenter said Sunday at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards. “So to get to be part of something, so more often than not, that is something that can bring you light, make you smile, make you dance, make you feel like the world is your fucking oyster — I am so grateful.” It's a perfect summary of pop fandom — but also everything that was missing from the VMAs this year. MTV's annual bash came up mighty short on star power, pop flash, celebrity egomania, humor, sleaze, madness, glitter-cringe misbehavior — you know, the kind of thing you watch the VMAs to see. It's one thing to begin with a Kenny G cameo. But it's another when Kenny G turns out to be one of the damn highlights. The night's best line came from Ariana Grande: “Thank you to my therapists and gay people! I love you!” Ariana was the MVP — one of the few big-deal stars who actually showed up, sure, but also someone the camera could always rely on for total unflagging enthusiasm. Every time the energy level sagged, which was often, they could cut to the Ari-Cam and catch her cheering or singing like she was genuinely excited to be here. She won Video of the Year for “Brighter Days Ahead” — yet the whole show would have been basically unwatchable without her. Thank you, Ariana's therapists and gay people! MTV owes you big-time. Ariana also presented the Video Vanguard award to Mariah Carey, who finally got her long-overdue career award after somehow never winning a single VMA in her career until now. “I can't believe I'm getting my first VMA tonight,” Mariah said in a hilarious speech. “I just have one question: What in the Sam Hill were you waiting for?” Popular on Rolling Stone This was the first VMAs aired on CBS, and there was plenty of rookie energy in the air. The network seemed to have trouble persuading actual stars to perform. They didn't dream up any clever moments or duets. They ran ads from the federal government trying to recruit ICE agents, a real middle finger to the audience. There was a glut of new legacy awards, as if they needed to cover up for their difficulty getting big names to return their calls. Busta Rhymes came on to do a medley of his hits — the exact same medley he did on the show just four years ago. Nikki Glaser, normally the life of the party at any award show, didn't even get to make any jokes. The weakest VMAs in years, after a five-year winning streak. What in the Sam Hill was going on? Editor's picks The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time On the bright side, you had to love all the 2000s energy. The whole night was full of millennial fever. When host LL Cool J said, “We've got icons in the house!,” the camera cut to Paris Hilton waving. (Some things never change.) There was a Burger King ad bumping Taio Cruz's “Dynamite,” then a cellphone ad starring Lindsay Lohan, saying, “Now that I'm a mom, things are, well, different!” MTV kept pimping their incredibly innovative cutting-edge ideas with promos for the “historic season finale” of Jersey Shore Family Vacation. (Dude, it's the first time Sammi is meeting Ronnie's parents? No way — time to pour some Ron-Ron Juice and get obliviated!) As a great woman once sang, the whole night was “So Yesterday.” And just when you thought it couldn't get any more 2000s, Ashlee Simpson made a proud return, radiating all her glorious “La La” evergy. Ashlee never loses her touch, proving that she was 100 percent right when she warned the world all those years ago — you can throw her like a boomerang, but she'll come back and beat you up. She came onstage with her sister Jessica, who also reminisced about “back in 1999,” when she was on tour opening for Ricky Martin, “the world's biggest pop star.” When Paris presented the Song of the Year award, her walk-on music was “Stars Are Blind,” which somehow failed to win this award back in the day. Related Content Ariana Grande Thanks ‘My Therapists and Gay People' During VMAs Video of the Year Speech Sombr Finds His Inner Heartthrob During VMAs Main Stage Debut J Balvin Brings Down the House With ‘Zun Zun' and ‘Noventa' at the 2025 VMAs Ozzy Osbourne VMAs Tribute: Steven Tyler, Joe Perry, and Yungblud Bark at the Moon Person Lady Gaga was one of the 2000s stars who defined the VMAs — some of us will ride forever for the night she hosted in character as her male alter ego Jo Calderon. So it's cool she dominated the show tonight, winning Artist of the Year. Then she rushed across town, from New York's UBS Arena to Madison Square Garden, so she could reappear live from her own Mayhem Ball, doing a spectacular gothed-out performance of “Abracadabra” and “The Dead Dance.” But Gaga dedicated her award to the audience. “The way you move for your life is iconic and rare,” she said. “It is entirely yours.” Mariah did a medley of her hits, including “Fantasy,” “Heartbreaker,” “Obsessed,” and “We Belong Together.” She also traded air kisses with Ariana, gushing “She's so little! You're the cutest!” Mariah reminisced about her long VMAs journey. “Being here brings back amazing memories,” she said. “Like when I presented LL Cool J with his Vanguard Award. Or when Whitney Houston and I opened the show with a faux stand-off, when we both had our dresses — we were like, ‘Try it on me!'” It's just a shame MTV couldn't persuade Jennifer Lopez to be part of the Video Vanguard tribute. (Hey, Taylor Swift came out 10 years ago to give this same award to “my friend Kanye West,” so there's precedent.) Sabrina took a Nineties trip for her live debut of “Tears,” turning a NYC street-party scene into a ballroom bash, as she waved the flag for transgender rights. Her dancers included a slew of drag queens and ballroom stars: Lexi Love, Simone, Leganja Estranj, Honey Balenciaga, Dashaun Wesley, Richie Shazam, Jewels Sparkles, Denali. Her dancers held signs that said “Protect Trans Rights,” “Dolls Dolls Dolls,” and “If You Hate You'll Never Get Laid.” The boom-box radio announced it was 69 degrees — “a wet one” — as Sabrina crawled out of a manhole. So yeah, she's still not into subtlety, fortunately for us all. Sombr, wow — now there's a showman who knows how to show, pure glitter sex-on-a-stick startime, with shoulder pads even Bowie would have coveted. He did a fantastic Studio 54 goth-glam “12 to 12,” opening with the words, “This one's for the girls that get it.” Best moment: One dancer crawled across the stage to slither up alongside him, then dropped to her knees before him, and he looked so sweetly embarrassed it was downright touching, without compromising any of his Mick Jagger/Richard Ashcroft stud-liosity. Never let anyone try to talk you into shirts that button, Sombr. You're better than that. Tate McRae did her thing on the floor, writhing acrobatically to “Revolving Door” and “Sports Car”— if you've seen her current tour, you know she can do two hours of this easy, going again like three-four times. Tate could have been designed in a lab as the perfect star for this award show — she taps right into the TRL aesthetic. She was born the summer of 2003, when Madonna and Britney had their historic VMAs kiss, and it's as if she were born from that kiss. Doja Cat went totally '80s for “Jealous Type,” opening with the smooth tones of Kenny G's soprano sax making sonic love to us all. She got all the era details right, heavy on the pastels, a guitarist in black leather and a cameo, a keytar queen in a Stacey Q-worthy perm, Jimmy Jam/Terry Lewis-style mall beats, all on a black-and-white checkerboard floor. With the Club MTV energy off the charts, you had to keep wondering if Downtown Julie Brown was about to give Doja some wubba-wubba-wubba love, or if MC Skat Kat would suddenly dish the dirt on stealing Paula Abdul's covers. But respect to Doja for finessing the fine points. Busta Rhymes won the brand new Rock the Bells Visionary Award — he complained about waiting 35 years to win it, so guess nobody told him this was the first one ever. GloRilla joined him for hits like “Scenario” and “Pass the Courvoisier.” A class act as always, Busta gave a moving salute to the late MTV VJ Ananda Lewis. Ricky Martin won another new honor, the Latin Icon Award, shaking his bon-bon in a medley of Nineties hits like “La Copa De Vida” and “Livin' La Vida Loca,” making you wonder what the voodoo-loving kink temptress in the song is up to these days. (Reiki yoga instructor, right?) “I am addicted to your applause,” Ricky said. “That's why I keep coming back.” But the highlight of this interlude was the moving fan tribute from J. Balvin. “I want to talk with my heart,” Balvin said. “Man, we love you.” It was one of the only moments all night (along with Ariana on Gaga) where the stars got to act like shameless music fans — the show could have used a lot more of that. Rosé won Song of the Year for her '80s-themed Bruno Mars duet “Apt” (somewhere, Toni Basil must have been happy) and gave a sweet speech where she thanked herself (it was her therapist's idea) and also dedicated the award to her 16-year-old self, remembering her awkward teen days when she felt like an “oddball.” Post Malone and Jelly Roll did a bromantic duet on “Losers,” appearing live from Germany. J Balvin got busy with Lenny Tavarez, Justin Quiles, and DJ Snake, while Lola Young did “Messy” and Alex Warren sang “Ordinary.” Megan Moroney rocked her emo-cowgirl anthem “6 Months Later.” She also won the first VMA for Best Country Video — a welcome sign of the times. Trending Stories US Open Crowd Booed Trump Repeatedly MTV VMAs 2025: See the Complete Winners List Ozzy Osbourne VMAs Tribute: Steven Tyler, Joe Perry, and Yungblud Bark at the Moon Person Rick Davies, Supertramp Co-Founder and Singer, Dead at 81 The Ozzy Osbourne tribute got hyped all night, right from LL Cool J's opening monologue, where he promised, “Tonight we are honoring a man known as the Prince of Darkness, who brought a lot of light into the world!” Aerosmith's Toxic Twins, Steven Tyler and Joe Perry, reunited for “Mama I'm Coming Home.” (Perry is on a hot streak these days, ripping it up on his excellent solo tour with the Black Crowes' Chris Robinson.) But Yungblud didn't have the vocal chops for “Crazy Train” or “Changes.” Sadly, Lita Ford didn't show — and why didn't Busta jump up there for his Ozzy duet “This Means War”? Why didn't we get Sabrina singing “Iron Man,” or Ariana belting “Children of the Grave”? But it said a lot about the void Ozzy left in the universe, after his tragic death this summer. Conan Gray closed out the night doing “Vodka Cranberry” in a red velvet cape, a look he should try more often, since Hammer-horror '60s Dracula mode works for him. He staged a Sleeping Beauty-style pageant, singing to an unconscious Stephen Malkmus look-alike in a frilly blouse (Girl Meets World star Corey Fogelmanis) on a bed of flowers, until Conan finally took a sip from a conveniently placed decanter of crimson liquid — vodka cranberry? A magic love potion? Or was it bloooooood? Honestly, hope it was the vodka — after a song that sad, Conan looked like he could use a drink. The Romeo-as-Juliet he was serenading was very conspicuously breathing, so we weren't in deathbed territory here, yet it was still a startlingly downbeat way to end an award show. But maybe he just felt a bit snoozy after such a sluggish VMAs ceremony — an understandable feeling after all so little excitement and spectacle. We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rolling Stone is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Rolling Stone, LLC. All rights reserved.

Inside Alexia Umansky & Jake Zingerman's Los Angeles Wedding [PHOTOS]
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-09-08 04:27:09

Alexia Umansky, daughter of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” star Kyle Richards and real estate mogul Mauricio Umansky, has officially tied the knot. Alexia married her longtime love, Jake Zingerman, in a Los Angeles ceremony on Sept. 6, surrounded by family and friends. A post shared by Page Six (@pagesix) The daughter of Bravo veteran Kyle Richards walked down the aisle in an elegant ivory gown with a taffeta bustier, while Zingerman wore a crisp white tuxedo jacket with black trousers and a bow tie. The celebration was a true family affair, with Alexia's sisters—Farrah Brittany Aldjufrie, Sophia Umansky, and Portia Umansky—serving as her maids of honor. Her cousin Nicky Hilton, daughter of Kathy Hilton, also shared a glimpse of the event on Instagram, posting photos of a rose-covered entrance illuminated by candlelight. Photos from the evening showed the bride's vision of an “enchanted evening garden” came to life with rich tones, sparkles, and eclectic touches, which she had described just days earlier during a livestream with her mother. Later in the evening, Alexia swapped her gown for a short lace minidress and danced alongside Jake as guests celebrated into the night. According to The Daily Dish, the wedding, originally planned for Aspen, was moved to California after the couple decided a destination event was too “stressful.” Richards and her husband, Mauricio Umansky, were in attendance to support their daughter on her big day. A post shared by TMZ (@tmz_tv) Both Kyle and Mauricio have shared their admiration for Jake over the years. Kyle previously described her daughter's husband as “a very, very, very cute” addition to the family. “They are a very cute couple, and they're great together,” she said during an Amazon Live stream. Mauricio also spoke warmly about Jake in a past interview with Us Weekly, saying, “He's awesome. We love him.” Their approval has been clear throughout the couple's engagement and wedding journey. A post shared by Alexia Simone Umansky (@alexiaumansky) Alexia and Jake, who began dating in 2019 after first meeting in grade school, already share a home in Los Angeles. In a recent Amazon Live appearance, Alexia revealed she will hyphenate her last name to Umansky-Zingerman. As for a honeymoon, the couple said they plan to delay the trip. “We're not gonna go right away,” Alexia explained. “It was too hard to plan the honeymoon and a wedding in such a short amount of time.” With a strong foundation of family support and a shared life already in place, Alexia and Jake are entering this next chapter with plenty of love around them. Carrie Underwood's 'Sunday Night Football' Theme Song Required More Than 80 Recordings
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-09-08 03:20:29

As NBC's “Sunday Night Football” kicks off on September 7, 2025, it will begin for the 13th year in a row with country superstar Carrie Underwood singing the latest version of the theme song, “Waiting All Day For Sunday Night.” The former “American Idol” winner and current judge says it's the thing she's most recognized for, according to the New York Times, which went behind the scenes of the June recording session, during which Underwood sang 80 versions of the iconic song, set to the tune of Joan Jett's 1988 hit “I Hate Myself For Loving You.” A post shared by SNF on NBC (@snfonnbc) The “Sunday Night Football” theme song changes slightly with every new NFL matchup across 18 Sundays, according to the New York Times. But because the primetime lineup can change later in the year, depending on which games are likely to draw the most viewers, producers have to be prepared for the intro song to pump people up for a variety of possible team and player matchups. That means Underwood recorded dozens of permutations of the rock song, standing in a dark Nashville studio in her bare feet, the outlet reported. For the September 7 game between the Baltimore Ravens and the Buffalo Bills, NBC producer Rob Hyland told the New York Times they wanted Underwood's lyrics to focus on superstar quarterbacks Lamar Jackson and Josh Allen. Underwood was given multiple different lines to record, with the freedom to change words here and there if the lyrics don't feel quite right. “It's just all about flow and the rest of the sentence,” Underwood told the New York Times. “You get in there and sometimes you'll sing something and it sounded clunky, and then somebody will be like, ‘Why don't you switch the names or switch the order?'” A post shared by SNF on NBC (@snfonnbc) 2025 marks the 20th season of “Sunday Night Football” on NBC. Tripp Dixon, creative director for the opener, told NBC Insider they wanted to give Underwood's theme song a special sound for the occasion. Dixon said, “For the 20th season of SNF, we wanted to set the tone for the night by reimagining the anthem sound in a way that plays to Carrie's powerhouse vocals, while visually creating a seamless blend of stylized shots and behind-the-scenes moments evoking the national roadshow that is Sunday Night Football, week after week in the fall.” Previous Next About Contact US Privacy Policy Terms Of Service Editorial Guidelines Sitemap Copyright © 2025 Heavy, Inc. All rights reserved. Powered by WordPress VIP

Keanu Reeves' Girlfriend Shares Rare Message to Him on His Birthday
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-09-08 03:20:29

Keanu Reeves is receiving all the love as he celebrates his 61st birthday with a sweet surprise from Alexandra Grant. Fans got a rare look inside Keanu Reeves' birthday thanks to his girlfriend. The artist posted a photo of his celebration, complete with a custom cake and a touching note. She posted a photo of a heart-shaped cake covered in white frosting and rimmed with black and white candies. Red gel icing spelled out “KEANU X.” Candles lined the edge. “Thank you to everyone for sending over sweet wishes for Keanu's birthday yesterday,” Grant wrote on Sept. 3. “He was well-celebrated!” Grant also shared a direct note to Reeves, who stays offline. “To Keanu—who saw this post as a draft!—I am so grateful for your love and partnership,” she wrote. “Now back to painting! Xo.” The couple, who made their red carpet debut in 2019, have kept much of their romance private. Reeves confirmed the relationship the following year, telling Parade in 2020, “It's been really wonderful to be with Alexandra. We enjoy each other's company, whatever that may be.” Read her sweet message here. Reeves and Grant first met in 2009 at a dinner party. They went on to collaborate on two books together: the 2011 release “Ode to Happiness” and the 2016 series “Shadows.” In 2017, they co-founded X Artists' Books. Grant has spoken openly about their later-in-life romance. “The good news about falling in love as an adult is that I had built my own career by the time that my relationship had begun,” she told People in 2023. “I feel very confident in the relationship on the red carpet. I feel confident on it alone.” The couple occasionally shares glimpses of their love in public. In April 2023, they kissed on the red carpet at the MOCA Gala in Los Angeles. Around that time, Reeves gave rare insight into his personal happiness. Asked about his last moment of bliss, he told People: “A couple of days ago with my honey. We were in bed. We were connected. We were smiling and laughing and giggling. Feeling great. It was just really nice to be together.” Keanu Reeves' 61st birthday celebration shows that even after decades in Hollywood and roles in “The Matrix,” “John Wick,” and “Speed,” some of his happiest moments are found offscreen with Alexandra Grant. ROSÉ Opens Up About Her Fears in ‘Deeply Personal' VMAs Acceptance Speech
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-09-08 01:52:30

She nabbed the song of the year VMA for her Bruno Mars collab "APT." By Joe Lynch Executive Digital Director While ROSÉ already has some VMAs in her back pocket thanks to BLACKPINK's several wins at the MTV Video Music Awards over the years, the New Zealand/South Korean singer now has one of her own as a solo artist – and the big moment was not lost on her. Bruno Mars & ROSÉ's smash “APT.” (which peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard Hot 100) was named the song of the year at the 2025 VMAs on Sunday (Sept. 7) night at the USB Arena in Elmont, N.Y. Taking the stage to accept the honor (Mars was not present at the show), Rosé unfurled a pre-written note and read a well-thought-out, personal speech. “I feel like this is a really big moment for myself and a lot of other people,” she began before pausing, laughing a bit and continuing. “Thank you so much, Bruno. I can't believe this. I'm gonna call you after, thank you so much for believing in me.” Trending on Billboard ROSÉ then brought it back in time. “Someone asked me the other day what my fear in life was and I was quite shocked at my own response. I had no idea how deeply personal this journey had been for me. I told them I feared that somewhere along this journey of pursuing my dreams I might hit a wall and disappoint my 16-year-old self who grew up always an oddball among society, who wished someday she could be herself and pursue her dreams like anyone else I saw on television.” Holding her speech and the Moon Person, she declared, “Twelve years later I dedicate this award to my 16-year-old self who dreamed and to all those who have watched me grow into the artist I am today. Every single one of you has put me here…. Now I believe there is no imposter in the world when MTV has given me this award at the VMAs.” Rosé thanked her team, her label, her fellow BLACKPINK members and “my loyal fans for believing in me.” “This is a really big moment for 16-year-old me and anyone else who has dreamed of being accepted equally for their hard work,” she said. “As my therapist tells me to do every day, I'd like to thank myself for not giving up even in the toughest of times.” Watch her speech below: Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rosé Thanks Bruno Mars, Blackpink, Herself for Song of the Year Win at VMAs
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-09-08 01:18:02

Rosé looked like she could barely believe she won Song of the Year at the 2025 Video Music Awards, but had a two-page speech prepared just in case. After Paris Hilton (who walked out to her own bygone hit of sorts, 2006's “Stars are Blind”) presented her with a win for “Apt.” with Bruno Mars, the Blackpink star giddily took the stage, shocked. “I've prepared something because I didn't want to mess this up and I feel like this is a really big moment for myself and a lot of other people,” she began before thanking Mars for his friendship and world-building. Rosé shared an anecdote about being asked her what her fear in life is. She realized, she said, it would be hitting a wall and disappointing her 16-year-old self, who she described as “an oddball among society that wished someday she, too, could be herself and equally pursue her dreams just as well as anyone else I saw on television.” She dedicated the award to that young version of her. Rosé also thanked the members of Blackpink in both English and Korean, as well as her family, and many members of her team. Before walking off with her “heavy” Moon Person, she added, “As my therapist tells me to do every day, I'd like to thank myself for not giving up, even in the toughest of times. Always remember you've got you.” Trending Stories U.S. Open Crowd Booed Trump Repeatedly MTV VMAs 2025: See the Complete Winners List Ozzy Osbourne VMAs Tribute: Steven Tyler, Joe Perry, and Yungblud Bark at the Moon Person Rick Davies, Supertramp Co-Founder and Singer, Dead at 81 Popular on Rolling Stone The nominees for this year's category were Alex Warren's “Ordinary,” Billie Eilish's “Birds of a Feather,” Gracie Abrams' “I Love You, I'm Sorry,” Lady Gaga and Bruno Mars' “Die With a Smile,” Rosé and Bruno Mars' “Apt.” and Tate McRae's “Sports Car.” This year's ceremony is taking place live from UBS Arena in Elmont, New York. LL Cool J is the host, and Lady Gaga is the most-nominated artist, with 12 nods. Mariah Carey was honored with the Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award while Busta Rhymes and Ricky Martin where awarded the Rock the Bells Visionary award and Latin Icon award respectively. Universal exec regrets sending Ludacris and Tyrese to space in Fast And Furious 9
Source: AV Club    Published: 2025-09-08 00:46:00

Lamenting the decision to allow fans to chart the course of the Fast And Furious movies, NBC Universal Chief Content Officer Donna Langley apologized for a scene in 2021's F9: The Fast Saga in which Tyrese Gibson and Ludacris' characters, Roman and Tej, don SCUBA suits and fly to the International Space Station in a rocket car. “I'm sorry that we sent them to space,” Langley said at the Toronto International Film Festival. “We can never get that genie back.” Though she did not offer an early apology for Vin Diesel's recent announcement that Brian O'Connor, the character played by the late Paul Walker, would appear in the next film, Langley admitted that most of the series' ideas come from fans. Citing Diesel as an “early adopter of talking to his fans directly,” Langley said that plot points, including the deaths of major characters like Michelle Rodriguez's Letty, were “led by fan engagement.” “[People would] sort of throw out little things about, ‘Oh God, don't kill Letty,'” Langley said. “OK, we'll bring her back. ‘She never died. Don't worry. Nothing to see here.' But that's all led by fan engagement.” Langley, who didn't apologize for the scene in F9 where Roman (Tyrese Gibson) realizes he and the rest of the family are immortal and possibly fictional characters inside a fake universe, says that the expansive silliness of the series was born out of a desire to help the franchise grow. “We made a conscious decision to pivot to a sort of a globe-trotting heist scenario,” she said. That doesn't quite explain how a globe-trotting heist scenario became a globe-orbiting one, nor was the initial apology necessary, as that scene in F9 is fun and funny. We'll accept the apology anyway and hope that getting this major regret off her chest helps Langley produce the ever-elusive Fast X: Part 2, which has yet to materialize. [via Variety] GET A.V.CLUB RIGHT IN YOUR INBOX Pop culture obsessives writing for the pop culture obsessed. ‘Pee-wee As Himself' and ‘SNL50' Win Big at Creative Arts Emmys Night Two
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-09-08 00:10:10

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. With just one week to go before the 77th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards, the television industry started the festivities with the Creative Arts Emmys, two nights of awards for technical and artistic excellence behind-the-scenes of the year's best shows. Night one honored key players in narrative fiction (though the results don't hint obviously at next week's big winners), and night two shifts to reality, variety, nonfiction, and documentary programming. Many of the September 7 awards went to the HBO documentary “Pee-wee as Himself” (including director Matt Wolf) and NBC's “SNL50” celebrating half a century of the iconic sketch comedy series. Ted Passon's “Patrice” won the award for Exceptional Merit in Documentary Filmmaking. “The Daily Show” picked up awards for writing and for specific segments, while “Love on the Spectrum” received accolades for Outstanding Unstructured Reality Program and for its casting. The Grammys, Oscars, and Beyoncé Bowl all picked up awards, as did streaming favorites “Cunk on Life” and “The Traitors.” Popular on IndieWire Related Stories ‘Black Rabbit' Review: Jason Bateman and Jude Law Shoulder an Unbearably Bleak Netflix Thriller One of the Best ‘Survivor' Seasons in Years Is Airing Right Now — Why Is It So Hard to Watch in America? Full Creative Arts Emmy Awards Night 2 winners list below. OTHER

Author who presented at Butler Paranormal Conference releases book
Source: Butler Eagle    Published: 2025-09-08 16:03:26

Maxim Furek, a presenter at the Butler Paranormal Conference, has released a book based on stories of paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren. “The Smurl Haunting: When Ed and Lorraine Came to Town,” has been published by Chicago's Anxiety Press and is tagged as “the true story about demonic possession in West Pittston, Pennsylvania.” Furek also said the Psychic Vincent Sisters, who are originally from Butler County, also provided insight to his book. “The Smurl Haunting” is on sale on Amazon.com. 514 West Wayne Street Butler, PA 16001
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Who Are The Space Invaders? Planetary Protection And The Role of Biological Interactions Between Extraterrestrial And Terrestrial Biospheres
Source: astrobiology.com    Published: 2025-09-08 15:25:09

Exploring our solar system and returning pieces of it to Earth is a central part of the existential quest to search for life beyond our home planet. Understanding the biosafety and biocontamination implications of landing on a planetary body or in bringing pieces of our solar system back to our home planet are the two themes that are central to planetary protection, a discipline that is unique to spacefaring nations. The nature of planetary protection is twofold: (1) to ensure that we minimize our own terrestrial microbial footprint on other planets and moons (planetary bodies) in our solar system (forward contamination), and (2) to ensure that we minimize the potential impact of returning samples from another planet or moon to Earth (backward contamination). The discipline of planetary protection focuses on who is the biological “invader” and when does their arrival indicate an “invasion”? The degree to which there is potential for biological or organic interactions that result in biocontamination or changes in biosafety posture is the central topic of this work. Who Are the Space Invaders? Planetary Protection and the Role of Biological Interactions between Extraterrestrial and Terrestrial Biospheres, Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Medicine via PubMed Astrobiology Explorers Club Fellow, ex-NASA Space Station Payload manager/space biologist, Away Teams, Journalist, Lapsed climber, Synaesthete, Na'Vi-Jedi-Freman-Buddhist-mix, ASL, Devon Island and Everest Base Camp veteran, (he/him) 🖖🏻 2025 © Reston Communications. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Russell Crowe's Supernatural Thriller That Grossed 4x Its Budget Surges on Streaming
Source: Collider    Published: 2025-09-08 14:54:00

Russell Crowe earned three Oscar nominations between 1999 and 2001, but he's since entered a different phase of his career, starring in a wide variety of films each year. He recently transitioned into the horror genre with his work on The Pope's Exorcist, the 2023 supernatural thriller telling the story of Father Gabriel Amorth (Crowe), the Vatican's leading exorcist, who investigates the demonic possession of an American boy in Spain. This leads him to uncover a secret the Vatican has kept buried for years. The Pope's Exorcist is streaming on Hulu in America but on Netflix globally, where it's entered the top 10 in several countries, including the Philippines. The Pope's Exorcist was not particularly well-received by critics, who rated the film a Rotten 50% on the aggregator site Rotten Tomatoes. Crowe's charm mostly landed with general audiences, though. The film currently holds a solid 81% on the audience-driven Popcornmeter. Despite negative critical reception, fans were extremely curious to see how Crowe's turn to the horror genre would be received, which led to the film finding massive financial success. It grossed $76 million at the box office against a modest $18 million budget, meaning it more than doubled its break-even point. The real Gabriele Amorth earned a writing credit for The Pope's Exorcist due to the movie being based on the stories he wrote about his time working for the Vatican. Jeff Katz teamed up with Chester Hastings, R. Dean McCreary, Evan Spilotopoulos, and Michael Petroni to write the script for The Pope's Exorcist, and Julius Avery stepped behind the camera to direct the film. Avery had previously worked with Sylvester Stallone on Samaritan, the critically panned superhero movie that's currently streaming on Prime Video. Russell Crowe will next star alongside Rami Malek and Michael Shannon in Nuremberg, which is coming to theaters on November 7, 2025. Richard E. Grant, Colin Hanks, John Slattery, and Leo Woodall have also been cast in the film, which wrapped production more than a year ago and has been seeking distribution since. The first trailer for Russell Crowe's Nuremberg was released at the end of July. James Vanderbilt, best known for his work as a scribe on Zodiac and The Amazing Spider-Man, is writing and directing Nuremberg. Check out The Pope's Exorcist on Hulu in America and Netflix globally, and stay tuned to Collider for more streaming updates. Your comment has not been saved We want to hear from you! Share your opinions in the thread below and remember to keep it respectful. Your comment has not been saved This thread is open for discussion. Be the first to post your thoughts. The Dark Turn in Fandom: How Online Spaces Became a Breeding Ground for Harassment and Doxxing
Source: Collider    Published: 2025-09-08 13:00:00

Note: Names marked with an asterisk are fake and used to refer to some sources throughout this article to protect their identities. I've been in fandoms my entire life, starting with The Vampire Diaries. I would read stories on Fanfiction.net, watch fanmade YouTube edits, have discussions about shipping with other fans on forums, and, of course, fight over ships on those same forums. From Doctor Who and Star Wars to K-pop and anime, fandom was my way of escaping reality. But when real life was occupying my time, my presence in fandom was less active. I was content with my private little bubble of enjoying things. That all changed last year, when I became obsessed with AMC's small-screen adaptation of Anne Rice's Interview with the Vampire and started seeking out connection again in online spaces, eager to recapture those same experiences I had as a high schooler on Tumblr. Instead, I was met with chaos. Admittedly, things were never all sunshine and rainbows back then, either, up to and including homophobic, transphobic, and racist censorship initiatives poorly disguised as concerns about violence and sex in fan works. Now, modern fandoms are littered with harassment, doxxing, and racist attacks that target Black, trans, and/or otherwise marginalized users who speak up against policing — and it's not showing signs of stopping any time soon. We've seen, in real time, how conservative pipelines work in online spaces — whether the crunchy-to-alt-right, the TERF (Trans-Exclusionary Radical Feminist), or the incel-to-alt-right version. It starts with specific rhetoric, planting the seed of fear into young, insecure minds. A specific group of people is painted as the enemies, dehumanized, and dogpiled with harassment. I set out to investigate if other people were having the same experience. Right away, someone else in the Interview with the Vampire fandom spoke up. Mica*, who prefers to remain anonymous for fear of doxxing, first joined fandom spaces at eight years old with Neopets before going on to be a part of the Harry Potter, Marvel Cinematic Universe, Homestuck, and even SuperWhoLock (Supernatural, Doctor Who, Sherlock) communities. “I feel as if fandom has largely lost a lot of its earnestness and creative drive, and has instead become largely reactionary, with non-creatives becoming BNFs [big name fans] based on takes and policing fandom,” they admitted. Similar to my own experience, Mica came up in the “DON'T LIKE, DON'T READ” era of fandom, where shipping non-canon gay pairings was seen as provocative and morally wrong. “Censorship is always a slippery slope, and the first people to be targeted will be the most vulnerable,” they said. It's true: The fight to censor gay works in 2002 and 2012 led to the mass purging of mature-rated fanfic on Fanfiction.net. One fan group, Critics United (described as a “volunteer fandom police”), mass-reported specific stories they deemed inappropriate by leaving abusive comments. As a person of color, Mica had experiences with other fellow fans, often other POCs, harassing and doxxing them for perceived injustices over fictional characters. “My harassment was acceptable because I hurt a fictional non-white man's feelings — and it was always a man,” they said. “Instead of reading anything I said as good faith, it became carte blanche to harass and bully me.” Mel Stanfill, Associate Professor of English at the University of Central Florida and author of Fandom Is Ugly: Networked Harassment in Participatory Culture, presented a study where they and their team looked at stories on Archive of Our Own (AO3) tagged as rape or non-consensual. Their research showed there were significantly fewer stories rated Teen or Mature, and more rated Explicit. “The argument we made is that people who otherwise would have been writing about this as a social issue have been scared away, or they've been locking their stories because we couldn't see those stories in our methods. They were invisible to us. Those other people are still posting them, but there was a real dramatic shift and the proportions of those stories changed,” Stanfill said. While the above concerns are valid and certainly experienced by plenty of fans, it's possible that there's a generational war at the heart of the issue. “My instinct is always [to ask], ‘Is this actually happening? Or is it more visible?' Like so much of fan culture, I think that's always been there, but it's just more visible,” said Dr. Ben Litherland, lecturer in Media and Cultural Studies at the University of Huddersfield, researcher, and co-host of the Ill Effects podcast. Algorithms play a huge role in this, one that entirely includes the collapse of context. People don't search hashtags on TikTok, Instagram, or Twitter anymore to find content; they let the platforms deliver the content to them. “Platformized algorithms [have] governed the systems. Twitter's a big part of this conversation, right? [Where you're] performing your fandom in front of the whole world, potentially. And just the affordances of that technology have always felt terrible, like some adorable 15-year-old who's learning to be political and a fan at the same time, and then they get quote-retweeted by everyone around, and they've got 50,000 people screaming at them because they've clumsily articulated something.” One fan I spoke with was present during the peak of one of the Internet's biggest fandoms in Supernatural. After initially joining during the show's fourth season, around 2008, they took a break from fandom in 2015, which lasted a decade. Now in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer fandom, a show they watched when they were younger, they've definitely noticed a difference in online interactions. “In the past, there wasn't so much discourse. People would argue, but it didn't launch entire bullying campaigns. Wincest and Destiel fans didn't agree on stuff, but it wasn't at the level of ship wars now. You wouldn't dox a person. You wouldn't harass them and encourage others to do [it], too. You'd argue in reblogs or asks, and that'd be it,” Dakota* said. Even a fandom known for its in-fighting and controversies, like Supernatural was back in the day, doesn't compare to what we're seeing now, but why? Dakota believes it's because of the political climate Gen Z and younger have grown up in. “The pressure to be so woke that it's performative, coupled with the hive mind and groups ganging up on folks, even making up things to justify such behavior, is just wild. 90% of the time, it's virtue signaling over something taken out of context or a made-up scenario,” they said. Ash, also known as @thisredwine on Twitter, has personal experience with this uglier side of fandom. While he got his fandom start dabbling in media like Star Wars, Vampire Academy, and First Kill, he's recently become more active in the Interview with the Vampire fandom, posting his thoughts after Season 2 of the show began airing from his perspective as a Black biracial trans person. “Getting to talk to so many people has been amazing — especially other Black and trans folk who've been in touch — but I've also been harassed really severely in the past few months,” Ash said. Within the IWTV fandom, Ash has been called anti-Black slurs, misgendered, and deadnamed several times on X in the last six months alone. He believes it's because he chooses to discuss the show from a race-centric perspective — which IWTV invites its viewers to do, considering the AMC adaptation changed the story's main character, Louis de Pointe du Lac, from a white slave owner to a Black Creole man. Beyond casting shifts, however, Ash has also called out the racism that lurks within the IWTV fandom itself. “BIPOC having honest, good faith conversations about fandom racism and implicit bias isn't ‘starting drama' or supporting censorship, but unfortunately, a lot of people operating in bad faith try to frame it that way,” he said. “We just want people to be more conscientious of how they might be perpetuating different forms of bigotry — whether that's implicit bias, microaggressions, racist stereotypes or tropes, or enabling outright hate campaigns and macroaggressions — and make an effort to do better.” While some in fandom spaces might claim they're anti-censorship and say they welcome all, their actions have demonstrated otherwise. “Their ‘anti-censorship' framework boils down to ‘it isn't OK to harass me or my friends for the fictional material we enjoy, but it's ok if we harass others and doesn't take into account how marginalized groups are always the ones affected first and worst by censorship,” Ash said. This self-policing is not coming from an outside source dictating how people should or should not behave in fandom circles. It's internal, inspired by systems that restrict people in their everyday lives outside the internet. “[It's] populist moral panic, which is a moral panic that is bottom-up rather than top-down,” Stanfill said. They've theorized this phenomenon is due to “context collapse,” a term used most commonly in social media academic research where online spaces have become more singular experiences, existing outside established context. In real life, people know how to behave at work versus at home, for example, but online spaces are different now, with everyone co-existing together, Stanfill pointed out. “Communities used to be in little enclaves, [with] the people writing these [explicit] stories and the people who just wanted to have nice fuzzy stories, didn't they interact with each other. They were in different spaces. But now with social media, with Tumblr, with AO3, with Twitter, hashtags or tags in general are bringing people together who ordinarily would have been in little enclaves before. So, there's a culture shock.” One fan artist, Jay*, who preferred to speak under condition of anonymity, describes their online fandom experience as more annoying than enjoyable. After some involvement in various video game fandoms, they're now active in spaces for anime like Golden Kamuy and Jujutsu Kaisen. They describe interacting in fandoms as constantly walking on eggshells. “It feels more negative and less fun each day. It's more about infighting than actually appreciating the original media. There is less analysis, less fan works, and more discussions about the moral aspects of fan work and moral interpretations,” they said. Having grown up in a religious community, it was hard for Jay to ignore the fact that a lot of fandoms have adopted many of the same conservative talking points, like the notion that violent video games and movies equate to violent actions. “Depictions of violence are seen as negative, despite these being fictional. they're called ‘glorification' rather than this violence being a part of the narrative,” they said. “In my community, we were discouraged from analyzing the messages of any media, and just judge based on their moral depictions of any topic, on a very superficial level.” Fandoms have now progressed from the earlier years of homophobic purging to queer being the norm to the present day, where lesbian and gay ships are often seen as fetishization. “While it's valid to not want to interact with sexual content, they have started referring to artists and writers as ‘gooners,' ‘perverts,' even ‘degenerates,' and ask others to harass or block.” This overcorrection problem in fandom is something Noor has seen, too. As a member of numerous fandoms throughout her life, including Harry Potter (specifically Marauders), Doctor Who, Supernatural, and One Direction, and currently Severance, Yellowjackets, and Taylor Swift, she's witnessed a different and unfortunate new trend in these circles. “I think there's been a rise in ‘puriteens,' a subset of fandoms that includes younger fans (not necessarily teens) who take umbrage with certain content — sometimes it's sexual content where the reasoning is ‘why is everything about sex?' but it's often also content where characters aren't portrayed as morally good all the time,” she said. “It feels like, at some point, people began policing things that are ‘problematic,' which at first does not seem like a conservative way to approach fandom, but it eventually morphed into a prescriptive approach to fandom where there's a right and wrong way to engage with characters and ships.” Sure, there's always been infighting in fan spaces, but things have taken a seriously dark turn in recent years. It's not limited to petty fighting, either; it's doxxing, harassment, stalking, slurs, and deadnaming. It's personal, and it's political. “[It's] a politics of disgust, right? It is about imposing your disgust on other people, and making your disgust the rule.” Stanfill said. Your comment has not been saved We want to hear from you! Share your opinions in the thread below and remember to keep it respectful. Your comment has not been saved This is a really insightful article but I think it could go deeper honestly. I'm a fandom old head too (mid 30s millennial), and I really noticed the shift mid and post covid. I don't think laying the fault entirely at Gen Z's feet is fair, but can you blame them? At least millennials grew up having kid specific spaces online where we could learn about how to interact with other humans on the internet. They didn't have that. And then they spent their most important adolescent years not even being able to see each other IRL. Their only spaces are on the internet. So it makes sense that the kind of interpersonal petty infighting they'd normally have with their real life friends are happening with strangers on the internet where, as the author rightly pointed out, they are clumsily still discovering their politics and points of view and are in a stage of psychological development where they have very strong opinions that they feel very passionate about. But the internet—and especially fast moving spaces like Twitter—are notoriously bad at giving people the grace and space to evolve and be wrong. It also feels VERY worth noting that this seems to have been written before SDCC when several IWTV fans, including one of the people interviewed here for having been doxxed, themselves doxxed a handful fans for, seemingly, not liking the “correct” ship. The SDCC incident involved a Black fan (who has been notorious in the fandom for previously doxxing other Black fans and calling them a number of anti-black slurs, again over which characters they ship) calling the San Diego convention center and other law enforcement to make a false charge that several fans who were attending the con were stalking one of the actors and intended him harm. YouTube creator Autumn Brown made a video explaining the incident in detail, but SDCC staff handled the situation extremely poorly and have made no move to rectify the situation. With regards to your previous comment, black fans, and especially the one being interviewed in this article, did not doxx people at SDCC. That is a bold faced lie and its frankly in extremely poor taste to spread it on an article about someone being stalked, doxxed and harassed for almost a year straight. Blaming random black fans for doxxings is disturbing to say the least, especially when the fans have proven time and time again that they had nothing to do with the SDCC or any other doxxing and when many of the black fans you are describing have been doxxed themselves. By spreading this rhetoric you are opening these black fans up to further harassment and You should really think about the things you spread online, especially with little verifiable proof CBR CBR CBR CBR CBR CBR CBR CBR CBR CBR

DIAMANTE slays the supernatural in new music video for “Silver Bullet”
Source: - // MELODIC Magazine    Published: 2025-09-08 12:45:23

Date: Glam-rock powerhouse DIAMANTE is a force to be reckoned with. The Coming In Hot singer is unapologetically herself in an epic 80s-Thriller inspired music video for her energizing summer single “Silver Bullet.” Comparable to legendary women in rock such as Bonnie Tyler, Joan Jett, and Lita Ford, the rising rockstar continues her message of female empowerment in this latest head-bang-worthy jam: “When she was a little girl / She knew she wanted the world / Nobody could kill her shine / There was nothing she couldn't survive…” Not afraid to stand in the face of danger, DIAMANTE embodies the perilous weapon just as striking as her commanding vocals. As the silver bullet herself, the monsters that judge her performance are no match for her prowess in this motivational, vibrant music video. Nothing holds back a woman who knows what she wants. DIAMANTE joined heavy rock band Bad Wolves on their melodic single “Hear Me Now,” as part of their debut album Disobey, which peaked at number two on Billboard's Mainstream Rock charts in 2018. The American singer gained national recognition with her successful tour in support of Shinedown on The Revolution's Live Tour in 2022 alongside The Pretty Reckless, promoting her independent album American Dream (2021). In 2024, DIAMANTE joined female-led bands Kittie and The Pretty Wild in an epic cover of Metallica's hit single “The Unforgiven” as part of the Queen of the Ring motion picture soundtrack. The powerful trio joins several other artists on the Sumerian Records project, including Corey Taylor, Bad Omens, Larkin Poe, and Kat Von D. DIAMANTE also appears on the American Psycho Comic Series Soundtrack with her fierce cover of “Love Is A Battlefield,” channeling rock legend Pat Benatar. “Silver Bullet” is available to stream on most streaming platforms. Tokyo's dark heart: The supernatural thrills of Underground Killer
Source: DLCompare.com    Published: 2025-09-08 11:28:41

The gamer's price-comparison tool In the neon-lit sprawl of a near-futuristic Tokyo, Tokyo Underground Killer immerses players in a gritty cyberpunk underworld. The game casts you as Kobayashi, a supernatural assassin dubbed the ''Shinjuku Vampire,'' entangled with the Gokuraku crime syndicate. The story unfolds through nearly 100 pages of hand-drawn comic scenes, blending dark humor and existential yearning. Kobayashi, a killer with a longing for a simpler life, hunts depraved psychopaths linked to Kinoshita, a deceased musician-turned-cultist. This narrative, steeped in supernatural intrigue and Tokyo's criminal underbelly, sets a feverish tone, with the city's catacombs hiding secrets about a demonic invasion by creatures known as Flatliners. The story's mix of violence and introspection creates a compelling backdrop, reminiscent of the cyberpunk noir found in Katana ZERO, though with a distinctly Japanese flavor. The game's world exploration is a love letter to Tokyo's iconic districts. Players traverse reimagined versions of Shinjuku, Akihabara, and Shibuya, each drenched in neon and cyberpunk aesthetics. Between intense missions, Kobayashi's apartment in Kabuki-Cho, Tokyo's infamous red-light district, serves as a personal hub where players can unwind. A city hub expands the experience, offering shops and mini-games like pachinko, UFO catchers, and arcade challenges. These elements ground the game in Tokyo's vibrant culture, with every alley and neon sign dripping with atmosphere. The catacombs, a labyrinthine network beneath the city, add layers of mystery, encouraging exploration to uncover narrative clues and hidden upgrades. Combat in Tokyo Underground Killer is a visceral, fast-paced affair centered on katana-based mayhem. Players slash, stab, and parry through hordes of Flatliners, demonic enemies inspired by Japanese folklore. The innovative Blood Skills system, fueled by collecting enemy blood, lets players unleash abilities like time-slowing strikes, armor-breaking slashes, or rocket-vaporizing bursts. With 10 upgradable skills and an ability tree, combat feels dynamic and strategic, demanding quick reflexes and tactical planning, especially during the game's 10 escalating boss battles. Paired with a pulsing electronic soundtrack, the combat's intensity matches the game's vivid world, making Tokyo Underground Killer a thrilling cyberpunk odyssey. Find the best prices for Tokyo Underground Killer using our price comparison tool.
